title: The Best (and Weirdest) Looks from London Fashion Week
text: Registered Return: First the New York Times article doesn't mention that one of the writers of the book, Robin Pogrebin, on which the article is based, attended Yale at the same time as Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh, and she doesn't claim in the book to have witnessed any untoward acts by Kavanaugh nor to have heard the rumors that supposedly swirled around the Ivy League campus about such actions taking place at parties. Then the New York Times article fails to mention that the man that is making the accusation, Max Stier, whom they only identify as a "former classmate" of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh and a CEO of a non-profit, is a lawyer that worked for President Bill Clinton and First Lady Hillary Clinton during the Lewinsky investigation, of which, Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh was a member of Independent Counsel Kenneth Starr's investigation into the Clinton administration. Oh, and the non-profit that Max Steir is CEO of, basically operates as an arm of the Democratic Party. But the biggest omission the New York Times made was to not inform the reader that the woman, at the center of this sexual assault accusation by Max Steir, doesn't recall any such incident ever occurring. This is a blatant hit piece by a once prestigious publication that now only peddles unsubstantiated accusations, conjecture, speculation, spite-based opinions, histrionics, hyperbole, half-truths, and outright lies, presented as fact based news, all to the benefit of the Democratic Party.
